TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-silty, isotic, isomesic Aquandic Durudepts

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON: Mathenycreek medial silt loam. (Colors are for moist soil unless otherwise stated. All textures are apparent field textures.)
Oi--0 to 2 inches; slightly decomposed twigs, needles, and leaves; clear smooth boundary. (1 to 6 inches thick)
A--2 to 9 inches; dark brown (7.5YR 3/2) medial silt loam, brown (10YR 4/3) dry; moderate fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic, and weakly smeary; many fine and very fine roots throughout; few very fine dendritic tubular pores; extremely acid (pH 4.4); clear smooth boundary. (7 to 11 inches thick)
Bw1--9 to 19 inches; brown (7.5YR 4/3) silt loam, yellowish brown (10YR 5/6) dry; weak medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; common very fine roots throughout; few fine irregular and few very fine dendritic tubular pores; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); diffuse irregular boundary. (5 to 15 inches thick)
Bw2--19 to 26 inches; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) silt loam, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) dry; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, slightly sticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots throughout; few fine irregular and few very fine dendritic tubular pores; few fine distinct irregular strong brown (7.5YR 5/8) redox concentrations; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); clear smooth boundary. (4 to 10 inches thick)
2Bw3--26 to 30 inches; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) very gravelly sandy loam, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) dry; weak fine and medium subangular blocky structure; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and slightly plastic; few very fine roots throughout; few fine irregular and few very fine dendritic tubular pores; few fine and medium distinct irregular strong brown (7.5YR 5/8) redox concentrations; 45 percent rounded mixed gravel; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); abrupt smooth boundary. (4 to 6 inches thick)
2Bsm--30 to 31 inches; dark reddish brown (5YR 3/3) cemented material that crushes to very gravelly sandy loam, strong brown (7.5YR 5/6) dry; massive; weakly cemented by iron; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); abrupt irregular boundary. (1 to 2 inches thick)
2C1--31 to 46 inches; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/6) very gravelly loamy sand, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) dry; massive; slightly hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine roots throughout; common fine irregular and few very fine dendritic tubular pores; 50 percent rounded mixed gravel and 5 percent cobbles; very strongly acid (pH 4.6); abrupt smooth boundary. (10 to 20 inches thick)
2C2--46 to 62 inches; dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) extremely gravelly sand, brownish yellow (10YR 6/6) dry; massive; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplsatic; few very fine roots throughout; many coarse and very coarse interstitial pores; 70 percent rounded mixed gravel and 5 percent cobbles; very strongly acid (pH 4.6).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION: Grays Harbor County, Washington; about 4 miles south of the Crane Creek Mill on the Quinault Indian Reservation; 730 feet north and 880 feet east of the southwest corner of section 2, T.22N., R.11W.; Latitude 47 degrees, 25 minutes, 13 seconds North and Longitude 124 degrees, 3 minutes, 0 seconds, West

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS: The mean annual soil temperature is 47 to 50 degrees F. The difference between mean summer and winter soil temperature is 5 to 7 degrees. The soils are usually moist and are dry for less than 45 consecutive days; udic moisture regime. The particle size control section averages 2 to 10 percent gravel and a total of gravel plus fine sand and coarser of less than 15 percent. Depth to the cemented layer (2Bsm horizon) is 20 to 40 inches from the mineral soil surface. Depth to redox concentrations is 15 to 25 inches. It has an umbric epipedon or an ochric epipedon that is too thin to qualify as a umbric epipedon.
The A horizon has 15 to 25 percent clay and 10 to 25 percent organic matter. It has moist bulk density of 0.70 to 0.90 g/cc. Phosphate retention is 85 to 100 percent and acid oxalate aluminum plus one-half the acid oxalate iron is 2 to 4 percent.
The Bw and 2Bw horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR moist and dry, value of 3 or 4 moist and 5 or 6 dry, and chroma of 3 or 4 moist and 6 dry. It is silt loam over gravelly sandy loam or very gravelly sandy loam. It has 10 to 30 percent clay, 2 to 10 percent organic matter, and 0 to 5 percent gravel in the Bw and 15 to 50 in the 2Bw horizon.
The 2Bsm horizon is 1 to 2 inches thick and is weakly cemented by iron.
The 2C horizon has hue of 10YR or 2.5Y moist and dry, value of 4 moist and 6 dry, and chroma of 4 or 6 moist and dry. It is very gravelly loamy sand or extremely gravelly sand. It has 0 to 10 percent clay, 0 to 3 percent organic matter, and 50 to 90 percent rock fragments.

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES: There are no competing series.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING: Mathenycreek soils are on till floored lake beds at elevations of 10 to 780 feet. Slopes are 0 to 5 percent. These soils formed from glacial outwash sands and gravels. The soils are in a mild marine climate and have cool, moist summers and cool, wet winters. The mean annual precipitation is 90 to 120 inches. The average January temperature is about 38 degrees F; the average July temperature is about 61 degrees F; and the mean annual temperature is about 49 degrees F. The frost free season is 180 to 220 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS: These are the Aabab, Kydaka, Mopang, and Southshore soils. Aabab soils are poorly drained and are greater than 60 inches to very gravelly outwash material. Kydaka soils are poorly drained and have a mucky surface horizon. Mopang soils are well drained and are 40 to 60 inches to dense till. Southshore soils are moderately well drained and have greater than 35 percent rock fragments in the particle-size control section.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY: Somewhat poorly drained; slow runoff; moderate permeability above the cemented material and slow through the cemented material.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION: Principle uses are timber production, wildlife habitat, and recreation. The major tree species are western hemlock, Sitka spruce and western red cedar. Understory species include salal, deer fern, blue huckleberry, and red huckleberry.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT: West side of the Olympic Peninsula in western Washington; MLRA 4A. Series is of small extent.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Portland, Oregon

ORIGIN.content: SERIES ESTABLISHED: Grays Harbor County, Washington, 2007; Quinault Indian Reservation.

REMARKS.content:
REMARKS: Diagnostic horizons and features recognized in this pedon are:
Ochric epipedon - umbric colors are 7 inches thick, thus horizon is not thick enough for umbric epipedon.
Cambic horizon - 9 to 30 inches
Weakly cemented by iron horizon - 30 to 31 inches
Outwash gravel - 26 to 60 inches
Particle-size control section - 12 to 30 inches average 10 percent gravel, and 5 percent or less fine sand or coarse sand.
All depths to the diagnostic horizon or other features as given in the range of characteristics is measured from the top of the first mineral horizon.
National Cooperative Soil Survey
U.S.A.
